Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Mechanical Behavior of Metal/Ceramic Nanolaminate Composites; Experiments and Simulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Natural and man-made layered structures exhibit extremely high strength, toughness, thermal resistance, and biocompatibility characteristics. On the microscopic scale, lamellar layered structures are the basic foundation for the high strength and toughness of steel as a structural material. Structures in nature, such as abalone and mollusk shells, derive their high strength and toughness from a layered ceramic structure bonded together by an organic glue. Indeed, the structure of engineering materials often mimics the structures in nature. Multilayered materials at the nanoscale exhibit exciting possibilities for extremely high strength, fatigue resistance, thermal resistance, wear resistance, and biocompatibility. Thus, designing layered structures at the nanoscale is a particularly attractive strategy for developing a new generation of multifunctional materials with tremendous possibilities. Nanolaminate materials have very different properties from traditional bulk composites, due to their much higher interfacial area and dramatically smaller length scale. These changes can lead to new types of deformation mechanisms, which are very different from those observed in bulk systems. Fundamental research on the mechanical behavior of metal/ceramic multilayers at the nanoscale is necessary for successful implementation of these materials in engineering applications.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This international project focuses on the high temperature behavior of multilayered metal/ceramic materials. Novel approaches to microstructural tailoring of the nanolaminates are being used to obtain a combination of strength and toughness. A systematic study linking synthesis, microstructure, deformation, and simulation, is critical to further development and understanding of nanolaminate composites microstructures and elevated temperature resistance. The focus of this work is on a model system of Ti/SiC multilayers at the nanoscale. This project involves Nik Chawla and his research team at Arizona State University and Jon Molina-Aldareguia at the Madrid Institute for Advanced Studies of Materials (IMDEA) in the Polytechnic University of Madrid, Spain (funded by the Spanish National Science Foundation). Also, there are strong linkages to researchers at Los Alamos National Laboratory. Cutting-edge techniques such as high temperature nanoindentation and in situ indentation in a scanning electron microscope (SEM) will be used. A new generation of graduate students is being trained with international experiences as inherent component of their research. Additionally, undergraduate students will be engaged in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this research is to explore the microstructure and mechanical properties of a relatively new class of materials, called nanolaminates, which contain layers of dissimilar materials in the nanometer regime. Layered structures are known to exhibit extremely high strength, toughness, wear resistance, thermal resistance, and biocompatibility characteristics. Therefore, they have become an area of interest in many avenues of materials research such as electronics applications, optical applications, and biomedical applications. These structures are also found in nature, such as Abalone and mollusk shells, which derive their high strength and toughness from their layered morphology. This work focuses on design and characterization of this new generation of novel materials with the aim of enhancing their mechanical properties such as strength, toughness, and wear resistance. Alternating layers of Al and SiC were used for this study. In metal-ceramic systems, the layered structure coupled with a very small length scale leads to new types of deformation mechanisms, which are very different from those observed in bulk systems.

 

Through this work, a thorough understanding of the deformation behavior of these nanolaminates was developed. The mechanical properties of the samples were correlated with the microstructure through 2D as well as 3D studies giving holistic information about the intrinsic mechanisms of deformation. Effect of sample volume, aspect ratio, layer thickness and layer orientation on the mechanical behavior was also evaluated. In order to achieve this, new and unique experiments were designed and novel micromechanical testing techniques were developed. This is important for materials research as mechanical testing in the micrometer regime is still being explored. One of the most significant achievements in this respect was the in situ testing of nanolaminates using lab-based X-ray tomography setup. This experiment was the first of its kind and also advanced the understanding of damage initiation in nanometer regime for this material system. These detailed experiments provided insight in the ways to enhance the microstructure and were used to develop novel co-sputtered layers of Al and SiC. This has come as a breakthrough as these samples not only display superior mechanical properties but also lead to a defect-free microstructure, therefore providing a work around for void formation, one of the biggest limitations of the sputtering process. A number of experiments through a wide range of techniques such as scanning electron microscope, focused ion beam, X-ray tomography, transmission electron microscope, nanoindenter, microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) has been conducted. This has enabled us to study the microstructure in 2D as well as 3D, the mechanical properties in tension, compression and shear, the deformation behavior ex situ as well as in situ, and the operative damage mechanism at the micro and nano level, making this one of the most detailed studies in the field of metal-ceramic nanolayered systems. 

 


Last Modified: 01/11/2018
Modified by: Nikhilesh Chawla
